awd_titl_txt: Crystal Chemistry and Properties of Zintl Phases: Towards Efficient New Thermoelectrics
awd_abstract_narration:
PART 1:   NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
The synthesis of new compounds and crystal structures remains an extremely important fundamental research endeavor in the pursuit of new technologically relevant materials. This research, funded by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program targets the synthesis of new compounds with technological applications, specifically thermoelectric applications. Thermoelectric materials can convert a heat gradient into electricity. The design of efficient thermoelectric devices is a major goal for energy conversion technologies. Zintl phases, which are a subset of intermetallics are ideal candidates for thermoelectric applications as they are semiconductors with complex structures which provide low thermal conductivity, which allows for precise tuning of carrier concentration. In this structure-property relationship study specific Zintl structures will be targeted to test ideas for property outcomes based on atomic-level modifications. The long-term goal is to discover new highly efficient thermoelectric materials. Short term goals include building an understanding of best Zintl structures for efficient thermoelectric energy conversion and discovery of new magnetic and electronic properties for other technological applications. With this NSF grant the principal investigator helps educate the next generation of the STEM workforce. Students from high school through graduate school are provided hands-on training and their scientific and social skills are developed through workshops and individual mentorship. The next generation of scientists is trained to consider novel materials and their impact on technology for our future energy needs and specifically thermoelectrics.

PART 2:   TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This grant supports fundamental research efforts to prepare new Zintl phase compounds and measure their properties with a goal of discovering new thermoelectric materials and enhancing their thermoelectric properties. The research focuses on studying a) new variants of 14-1-11 Zintl phases for which high zT is expected at high temperatures, and b) novel Europium-based materials exhibiting low thermal conductivity. New compounds are synthesized as single crystals, high purity powders and pellets via flux, metallurgical routes, and spark plasma sintering. A suite of physical characterization techniques is utilized, including single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction, electron microprobe, electrical and magnetic measurements. Structure and phase composition is subsequently correlated with electronic and thermal transport properties. With this NSF grant the principal investigator mentors science students starting their science careers in high school to undergraduates in partnerships with graduate students, ultimately providing professional training for scientific careers. Students are provided hands-on training and their scientific and social skills are developed through workshops and individual mentorship. The research is presented at national and international meetings and the findings published in peer-review journals.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on the synthesis of new compounds and crystal structures of Zintl phases for technological applications. Manuscript disseminated via peer review journal publications have elicited national interest in Zintl phases for several applications, such as energy conversion and storage applications and as quantum materials. The importance of Zintl phases for discovery of efficient thermoelectrics (materials that convert heat into electricity), along with the demonstration of novel electronic and magnetic properties was highlighted. Zintl phases are compounds made up of elements that are considered metals or metalloids on the Periodic Table. However, even though these compounds are made up of all metallic elements, when formed in specific compositions, they can display the properties of a semiconductor. That is that their electronic behavior can be tuned. When the material is placed between and hot and cold junction, electricity can be generated. To keep that generation constant, the material needs to have thermal properties of an insulator. Therefore, an efficient thermoelectric material has electronic properties of a semiconductor with thermal properties of an insulator. Zintl phases can have low thermal conductivity and good electronic properties. New Zintl phases with good thermoelectric efficiency were discovered and their structure and properties reported. During this timeframe, we have discovered two new Zintl phases with thermoelectric high efficiency. Yb2-xEuxCdSb2 is a compound that provides good electrical properties with very low thermal conductivity and provides high thermoelectric efficiency in the mid-temperature (300-500 ˚C) range when x = 0.3. Theoretical calculations attributed the low thermal conductivity to the layered nature of the structure. Yb21Mn4Sb18 was another new compound discovered with high efficiency at slightly higher temperatures (500-700 ˚C). Pair distribution function (PDF) analysis was employed to probe the local disorder within a complex Zintl phase (Yb21Mn4Sb18). Isovalent substitutions of elements in these compounds provided important information on the impact of various structural components on the electronic and thermal properties.  An improved thermoelectric figure of merit, power factor, and mechanical properties for the Zintl phase Yb14MgSb11, which is an efficient material for the 700-1200˚C range, was demonstrated. Composites of this compound with 1-8 vol % reduced Fe powder were prepared via a fast, scalable, mechanical milling and spark plasma sintering procedure. Imaging techniques showed that the Fe inclusions are larger and closer together with increasing Fe content. When the Fe inclusions were nano- rather than micron-sized, the positive effects on the properties were improved further.

New Zintl phases with unique magnetic and electronic behavior were discovered and their properties reported. The complex compound, Eu11Zn4Sn2As12, was prepared and the magnetic properties systematically investigated by substituting Sr for Eu. These compounds crystallized in a layered structure with the Zn2As6 ethane-like pillars modulated in their stacking. The magnetic structure was postulated and the low temperature magnetoresistive behavior highlighted. The series of compounds, Yb14MSb11 (M = Mn, Mg, Zn) were determined to contain intermediate valence Yb which impacts the magnetic, electronic, and thermoelectric properties.

During this project, the work of 8 graduate students and several undergraduates were supported. Students were trained on single crystal growth for structure determination and synthesis of high purity powders to press into dense pellets with spark plasma sintering for the property measurements. Students were training on a suite of physical characterization techniques such as SEM, TEM, electrical and magnetic measurements. Undergraduate students were mentored in the research enterprise and presented their projects at local scientific research meetings. Graduate student research projects were presented at national meetings and published in peer-review journals.
